content.title: Contained Aortic Rupture
content.description: A form of aortic rupture where hemorrhage is initially contained by the retroperitoneum or periaortic tissues, allowing temporary hemodynamic stability.
content.definition: Contained rupture refers to aortic wall disruption where extravasation is tamponaded by surrounding tissues (retroperitoneum, posterior pararenal fascia), providing a temporary window for diagnosis and intervention before free rupture occurs.

pathophysiology: Can decompress into free rupture at any time
clinical_presentation: Severe abdominal or back pain (often present for hours-days)
May have flank ecchymosis (Grey Turner sign - delayed)
Can present as syncope with recovery
imaging_findings: CT: Periaortic hematoma with contained contrast
management: EVAR if anatomically suitable - faster control
Prepare for conversion to free rupture at any moment

learning_objectives: Distinguish contained from free aortic rupture
Recognize CT findings of contained rupture
clinical_pearls: Patient with contained rupture may walk into ED - don't be fooled by stability
Pain out of proportion to exam in known AAA = presume rupture
'Draped aorta' sign = posterior wall draped over vertebra (no retroperitoneal tissue plane)
Contained rupture can decompress into free rupture with hypertension or straining
These patients are one cough away from exsanguination
